column1: Taiwan;TWTAIPEI01 - National Taiwan University (NTU);2017/2018;Fakultät für Betriebswirtschaftslehre - BWL;Betriebswirtschaftslehre
column2: Bachelor - BWL_B_BWL;264508;"I received great support from the NTU side during planning and preparation phase. Right after I was accepted
column3: I was contacted by the NTU International Office. The international coordinator was very friendly and helpful
column4: she sent me emails with the next steps and replied to my questions immediately. She also created the Facebook group for all exchange business students and posted there all  relevant information.

column1: There were a couple of things I had to prepare before I got my official admission letter: health form
column2: insurance and a questionnaire. It is better to plan around two weeks for getting the health form
column3: because you need to provide your doctor with X-Ray
column4: necessary injections etc.
column5: so the sooner you start
column6: the less stress you have. You also need to provide the confirmation that you are insured throughout your whole stay. As for the questionnaire
column7: there you have to tell if you want to take a Chinese course and if you are interested in getting a room at the dormitory. I got allocated to a double room and later in august was contacted by the dormitory about the transfer of the pay for September. The communication went very clear and smooth.

column1: As a Russian citizen
column2: I applied for Taiwanese visitor visa. For that I sent my documents to München and got my Visa 3 days later
column3: conveniently and quickly sent to me by post.

column1: Before I came to Taiwan
column2: I got a contact of my NTU Buddy
column3: who answered all my questions concerning courses registration
column4: university
column5: dormitory etc. Additionally
column6: I was assigned to a Facebook buddy group with 7 other exchange students
column7: and through that I could get to know some people before the semester had started.";"I got accommodated at the Prince House Dorm. Before I applied for the dormitory
column8: I was informed that they had limited rooms and could not guarantee that I get one. Anyway
column9: every Mannheim student got a room
column10: so I would totally recommend to apply. The walk from the dorm to the College of Management
column11: where I had most of my courses
column12: took around 15 minutes/ 5 minutes by bike. Staying at the dorm was less expensive compared to Mannheim: I paid around 160$ monthly for the double room plus around 7$ for the electricity.

column1: I was lucky to have a cool Belgian roommate
column2: who was also an exchange student at the College of Management. Our room had a fridge
column3: shower
column4: toilet and air conditioner
column5: each of us got her own table
column6: bed and chair. The room was clean
column7: and everything worked fine. If we had any problems or questions
column8: we could always approach people at the reception
column9: who were there 24/7. Nevertheless
column10: rooms do not have a kitchen
column11: because all students normally eat outside at the various food courts on campus or buy food at the convenience store right at the corner. There was no wifi in the room
column12: but you could access it if you buy a router or if you go to the lobby.";"At the beginning of august I was asked to do the first step of the course selection online
column13: which in the end was just a formality. Anyway
column14: in the first step you have to apply for the courses you like the most
column15: and after that system allocates you to the courses according to your preference and courses capacity. The second phase consists of the same procedure two weeks later. Even if the system does not allocate you to any courses
column16: do not worry! You can still apply for the courses again during the third phase
column17: which takes place during the first two weeks of the semester. During these two weeks you can visit different courses and decide which ones you like and which ones you do not. To get accepted for your courses you need to email the professor or approach them directly in class
column18: showing interest in the course. Normally
column19: it should not be a problem.

column1: The semester started from the 11th of September and ended on the 12th of January. I had my last presentations and Chinese exam in the last week of the semester
column2: but some courses ended before Christmas
column3: so students who did not have any classes in January could leave earlier and go home or travel.

column1: As a Mannheim student
column2: I needed 15 local NTU ECTs
column3: which would equal 30 Uni Mannheim ECTs. Therefore
column4: I took 5 courses for 3 ECTs each. NTU offers a variety of courses in different business fields
column5: so it should not be hard to choose. Four of my courses were management-related and one was Chinese language course. Almost all of my courses had mandatory attendance
column6: but it was not a problem
column7: because the courses took place from Monday to Wednesday and I still had enough time to travel.

column1: The workload was equally spread throughout the semester – we had to prepare and submit assignments
column2: prepare homework and presentations with other students and for some courses write the exam in the end. One of the challenges was groupwork
column3: because most of the students just need to pass and are not interested in grades. Nevertheless
column4: the pressure is less than in Mannheim because I did not have a real exam phase
column5: mostly just different projects weekly.

column1: NTU has a great campus
column2: which is considered one of the best parks in Taipei. You can have lunch under the palm trees
column3: make use of the food courts or ride a bike along the university alleys. NTU has a great library
column4: which is opened daily till the late evening and provides a good learning environment and all necessary modern facilities
column5: just like our libraries in Mannheim. Taiwanese students also study hard throughout the semester
column6: so sometimes you can see them napping on the library`s sofas to take a break from their work.

column1: Be prepared that you might have to spend some money on books and HBS articles
column2: professors usually inform the students in the first weeks if they need the books or not.";"Taipei was a perfect city for me as an exchange student. Not too crowded and not too loud
column3: it has something to offer for everyone. One semester was not enough to discover all the amazing places
column4: temples
column5: old streets and parks of this city. Every week there were interesting events in the city
column6: starting from exhibitions and finishing with a rich night life. A lot of local clubs offer student nights with free entrance and drinks
column7: so you will never get bored. If you like doing sport
column8: you could join sport programs at the university
column9: visit dancing classes for free or join the local gym.

column1: One of the best things about Taiwan was food. There are numerous food courts at the university where you can get a good lunch for 2-3 euro
column2: drink the famous Taiwanese bubble tea
column3: try local and foreign cuisines. Additionally
column4: University is located right in front of the Gongguan Night Market
column5: which is opened in the evenings and also offers various food options. If you want to try something new
column6: you can always take a bus or subway to other Night Markets
column7: which are located all around the city. There you can try green onion pancakes
column8: different kinds of tofu
column9: seafood and buy fresh fruit. The public transport usually works till midnight
column10: but you can always take an Uber or a taxi
column11: which are safe and have reasonable prices.

column1: The public transportation is very easy and convenient. During the registration you will get a student Easy Card
column2: which you can also use to pay for the subway and bus tickets. With the card you get a student discount for public transportation in the city and you do not need to use cash every time.

column1: Most of my time I spent with other exchange students
column2: who became my companions in travel times or simply when going out. One of the most fun things in Taiwan
column3: which I would totally recommend
column4: would be going to Karaoke. I went there a couple of times with my exchange friends
column5: it was always super exciting and created the best memories.

column1: One of the things you would need to get used to is the humidity. Humidity made the heat in the summer time feel much stronger than it was
column2: so be prepared to sweat. In comparison
column3: when the weather got cooler in winter
column4: the cold also felt much worse than it actually was. Therefore
column5: take a warm jacket with you or be prepared to buy it in Taiwan and expand your luggage space.

column1: Taiwan is a beautiful country
column2: which offers many travelling opportunities. Although there is no beach in Taipei
column3: there is a Fulong beach in 1
column4: 5 hours from the city
column5: so do not miss the opportunity when the weather is sunny. Besides
column6: I would recommend going to the south (Kaohsiung
column7: Kenting)
column8: where it is warm throughout the whole year
column9: visit Hualien and explore the places around Taipei. Travelling with a train from the North of the island to the south takes around 3 hours
column10: which is really fast. Even if you do not have a whole weekend free for travelling
column11: you can do various day trips from Taipei and discover surroundings. Additionally
column12: Taiwan is located right in the middle of Asia
column13: which makes it easy to travel to other countries nearby: Hong Kong
column14: Philippines
column15: Vietnam and Japan.

column1: Taiwanese belong to the nicest people I ever met – they are always ready to help you and very friendly to foreigners
column2: even if they do not speak English. I took the Chinese class
column3: so in the end of the semester I could order myself food
column4: understand numbers and lead simple conversations. I would recommend taking the Chinese course
column5: because it gives you better understanding of the culture and makes communication easier
column6: but as the most intense of my courses it demanded a lot of work and preparation.";My costs for Visa were around 80 euro
column7: total monthly costs for the dormitory around 150 Euro
column8: food around 5-8 Euro per day. Travelling around Taiwan is not expensive if you are ready to stay at hostels. Anyway
column9: due to travelling and leisure activities my expences were similar to expences in Mannheim - around 500-600 Euro monthly.;I do not have any tips for funding the stay abroad.;"PTCSL7908 / General Chinese Language Course (I)  / 3 ECTS / accredited / English / participation
column10: homework
column11: regular tests
column12: lesson reviews and final exam / Probably the most intense course I had. Very interactive course
column13: requires a lot of work and preparation for every class. Course ended in January. Recommended
column14: if you are ready for a weekly commitment and interested in the language.

column1: MBA5074 / Leading Teams and Organizations / 3 ECTS / accredited / English / two group projects
column2: participation
column3: replies to forum questions and a quiz / One of my favorite courses
column4: very competent and structured professor
column5: interactive course and evenly spread workload. Course ended in January. Recommended!

column1: GMBA7067 / Cross-Cultural Management / 3 ECTS / accredited / English / one group project
column2: individual assignment
column3: participation and final exam
column4: which was 20% of the grade / Very insightful course. Professor is nice and friendly but sometimes not very structured. The course ended before Christmas. Recommended!

column1: GMBA5016 / Corporate Social Responsibility / 3 ECTS / accredited / English / no final exam
column2: 50% participation
column3: 50% preparation of the book seminar / Very interesting and interactive course
column4: professor is very competent in her field. You need to prepare a lot of readings for the course but in the end you really have understanding of the modern CSR concepts. The course ended before Christmas. Recommended
column5: if you are ready for relatively bigger workload.

column1: GMBA5020 / Human Resource Management / 3 ECTS / accredited / English / two group projects and final assignment / One of my favorite courses! Professor is an entrepreneur with a lot of experience
column2: he is friendly
column3: charismatic and open to questions. The workload was okay and the course ended before Christmas. Recommended!";NTU was definitely the best choice I could make and if I had to choose again
column4: I would not change a thing. I fell in love with Taiwan
column5: got to know new cultures
column6: amazing people and learned a lot. The best thing about my semester at NTU was for me a combination of high quality education – I enjoyed all of my courses
column7: – and exciting daily adventures
column8: which included travelling
column9: food
column10: friends from all over the world and the awesome Taipei. I did not have the worst experience
column11: but as I said
column12: it was not easy to get used to humidity and hot temperature in the first months
column13: but that did not affect my positive impression of Taipei in any way. I had the time of my life in Taiwan and recommend it to everyone!;https://www.service4mobility.com/mannheim/DispQuestionServlet?identifier=MANNHEI01&kz_call=A&sprache=de&org_id=72&q_set_nr=ERFAHRUNGSBERICHT&pk_table_name=bewerbung&pk_name=bew_id&inst_id_logo=413686&use_jsp=1&pk_id=209019&bew_id=209019;2024-04-21 23:03:12.767364

column1: Taiwan;TWTAIPEI01 - National Taiwan University (NTU);2017/2018;Fakultät für Betriebswirtschaftslehre - BWL;Betriebswirtschaftslehre
column2: Bachelor - BWL_B_BWL;264473;Bei der Vorbereitung auf das Auslandssemester an der National Taiwan University wurde ich tatkräftig von der Betreuerin für Austauschstudenten
column3: Yvonne Chen
column4: unterstütz. Über eine Facebook-Gruppe informierte sie alle Austauschstudenten über die anstehenden administrativen Aufgaben und Deadlines. Die Anmeldung der Kurse erfolgte im Mai und stelle keine Schwierigkeit da. Diese Kursauswahl ist zunächst unverbindlich und kann noch in den ersten Vorlesungswochen geändert werden. Ein Visum braucht man als EU-Bürger nur dann
column5: wenn man nicht spätestens alle 90 Tage aus Taiwan ausreist. Jedoch verlang die NTU ein Gesundheitszeugnis welches einem von seinem Hausarzt werden muss. Dies beansprucht etwas Zeit ist aber gut machbar
column6: da ausreichend Zeit bis zur Deadline ist. Insgesamt lief die Vorbereitung reibungslos und wurde von Seiten der NTU sehr gut betreut.;"Während der Vorbereitungsphase konnte man sich online für das Studentenwohnheim der NTU anmelden. Hier hat man die Wahl zwischen einem Einzelzimmer und einem Doppelzimmer. Die Studentenwohnheime der NTU sind direkt am Campus gelegen und werden von einem privaten Anbieter betrieben. Ich habe während meines Aufenthalts in Taiwan in einem der Studentenwohnheime gewohnt
column7: kann sie jedoch nicht bedingungslos weiterempfehlen. Die Einzelzimmer sind sehr geräumig und das Preis-Leistungsverhältnis stimmt auch. Jedoch ist zu bemerken
column8: dass die meisten Badezimmer völlig verschimmelt sind und es im Winter in den Zimmern sehr kalt wird
column9: da diese über keine Heizung
column10: sondern nur über eine AC verfügen. Darüber hinaus war das Zimmer
column11: sowie das gesamte Wohnheim
column12: bei meiner Ankunft völlig verdreckt. Die nach Männern und Frauen getrennten Wohnheime der NTU haben jeweils ""Gemeinschaftsküchen""
column13: welche allerdings nur aus einer Mikrowelle und einem Reiskocher bestehen. Das Zahlung der Miete und der Check-In-Prozess gestalten sich wahnsinnig umständlich
column14: was viel Zeit und Nerven kostet. Dennoch überwiegen die gute Lage an der NTU und das Gemeinschaftsgefühl der Bewohner die genannten Nachteile.";"Das Studium an der NTU ist mit dem der Universität Mannheim nur schwer zu vergleichen. Die Auswahl an englisch sprachigen Kursen ist sehr begrenzt aber dennoch lassen
column15: sich meines Erachtens nach
column16: genügend spannende und interessante Kurse finden. Häufiger bekommt man bei der online Kursvoranmeldung keinen Platz in den gewünschten Kursen. Das ist nicht weiter schlimm
column17: da man in der ersten Vorlesungswoche die entsprechenden Dozenten darum bitten kann noch in den Kurs aufgenommen zu werden
column18: was auch meist möglich ist. Die Kursanmeldung ist erst nach der zweiwöchigen Add-and-Drop Phase endgültig
column19: dies gibt einen die Möglichkeit einen Kurs auch wieder abzumelden. Ich würde empfehlen in den ersten zwei Wochen so viele Kurse wie möglich zu besuchen als auch zu belegen um sich dann am Ende der Add-and-Drop Phase für seine Favoriten entscheiden zu können. Die Absprache der Kurse mit der Uni Mannheim hat reibungslos und zügig geklappt. Bei dem administrativen Prozess der Kursanmeldung wird man auch sehr gut von seinem Buddy
column20: ein einheimischer Student der NTU
column21: begleitet. Darüber hinaus kann man sich auch jederzeit mit seinen Fragen direkt an die Dozenten wenden.

column1: Die Noten der Kurse setzen sich meist nicht nur durch Klausuren zusammen
column2: sondern vor allem durch Anwesenheit
column3: Mitarbeit
column4: Präsentationen und Hausaufgaben. Besonders habe ich das persönliche Verhältnis zu den Dozenten geschätzt
column5: welches man von der Uni Mannheim nicht kennt. Auch die interessanten und interaktiven Vorlesungen ist man von seiner Heimatuniversität nicht gewohnt. Der Arbeitsaufwand ist wesentlich geringer als an der Uni Mannheim. Jedoch ist das Arbeitspensum gleichmäßiger über das Semester verteilt
column6: da man in einigen Kursen keine Klausur am Ende des Semesters schreibt. Die Benotung der Leistungen ist sehr fair und so ist es vergleichsweise leicht sehr gute Noten zu erzielen. Die Englischkenntnisse der Dozenten sind ausreichend. Der einzige Wermutstropfen ist die Dauer der Vorlesungen welche meist bei drei Stunden liegt. Des weiteren finden an Weihnachten auch Vorlesungen statt zu denen man als Austauschstudent nach abspreche mit den Professoren jedoch nicht erscheinen muss. Teilweise ist es auch möglich nach Absprache mit allen Dozenten bereits vor Weihnachten die Heimreise an zu treten. In den meisten Fällen hat man freitags sowie teilweise donnerstags keine Vorlesungen und kann über das verlängerte Wochenende verreisen.

column1: Ein Highlight der NTU ist der wunderschöne und weitläufige Campus. Hier lassen sich nicht nur eine Vielzahl an food courts finden
column2: sondern auch ein Schwimmbad sowie ein Fitnessstudio. Aufgrund der Größe des Universitätsgeländes empfiehlt es sich ein Fahrrad anzuschaffen.";"Die asiatische Großstadt Taipeh hält alles bereit was das Herz begehrt. Auch wenn Taiwans Hauptstadt nicht ganz so westlich ist wie andere asiatische Großstädte bekommt man dank der vielen europäischen Produkte keinen Kulturschock. Vom künstlich beschneiten Weihnachtsmarkt im Winter bis hin zu deutschen Bio-Lebensmitteln lässt sich alles in Taipeh finden. Das einzige gewöhnungsbedürftige ist das Wetter. Entweder ist es wahnsinnig heiß oder es regnet in Strömen. Dennoch gibt es im Winter auch recht kühle Tage.

column1: Mein Freundeskreis bestand vor allem aus Austauschstudenten aber auch aus einigen Einheimischen. Zusammen haben wir die abwechslungsreiche Stadt Taipeh und die schönsten Ecken Taiwans erkundet. Dabei war es oft sehr hilfreich
column2: dass einheimische in unserer Gruppe wahren
column3: da man gerade in ländlicheren Region mit Englisch oft nicht weit kommt. Die Taiwaner sind generell sehr freundlich und aufgeschlossen
column4: so entstehen schnell Freundschaften mit Locals. Auch wenn Taipeh keine touristische Stadt ist
column5: gibt es hier einiges zu entdecken und man sollte sich dafür genügend Zeit nehmen. Besonders zu empfehlen ist das Palace Museum welches die bedeutendste und größte Sammlung chinesischer Kunst ausstellt. Aber auch die Vielzahl an innerasiatischen Flügen macht es möglich die fernöstlichen Kulturen näher kennen zu lernen und Kommilitonen zu besuchen. Jedoch gibt es nur einen täglichen Direktflug nach FRA.";Die Lebenshaltungskosten sind mit denen in Deutschland zu vergleichen und wesentlich geringer als in anderen asiatischen Großstädten wie Hongkong oder Seoul. Das Studentenwohnheim sowie Wohnungen in Taipeh haben ein gutes Preis-Leistungs-Verhältnis.;Über spezifische Stipendienprogramme bin ich nicht informiert.;"PTCSL7908/ General Chinese Language Course (I)/ Chinesisch

column4: die ich Vorort kennen gelernt habe

column6: welches viel zu bieten hat.
